Their economy is already fragile, but now they're find it difficult to insure their shipping, to find fuel for their aircraft, to bank in the fashion that they've accustomed to banking internationally.
And this pressure is actually creating greater opportunity for diplomacy.
And that's the aim.

Privately, are you hearing anything different?
Well, Neal, I think it would be unusual to expect Ahmadinejad, with his penchant for bluster, to come to New York and say the sanctions are killing me.

peace enforcers in Somalia.

Well, there's no doubt that the situation in Somalia is extremely precarious.

The United States and others in the international community are clear in their support for the transitional federal government, but that's a fragile government that only controls a portion of the capital, Mogadishu, and is being supported by an African Union peacekeeping force that we've contributed a great deal of resources to and logistical support.
The aim is to build up the capacity of the African Union to expand its control over Mogadishu in support of the transitional federal government.
And to do that, it needs more troops.
It needs more logistical support.
It needs more resources.

So we're discussing, here at the United Nations, how to muster that additional support so that the African Union forces and indeed the government can be a sustained and credible bulwark against al-Shabab, which is closely affiliated with al-Qaida, and against other extremists that are terrorizing the population of Mogadishu and beyond.
Have you spoken with the Kenyan foreign minister about his idea?
I have spoken with the Kenyan foreign minister.

He was in New York last week at the Security Council, where he made a very powerful plea for the international community to understand just how grave a threat the situation and lawlessness in Somalia poses to countries in the region, including Kenya.
We're very close to Kenya and to other neighbors of Somalia in working to support them as they seek a solution both diplomatic and security to the situation in Somalia.

We've been actively supporting the Ugandan and Burundian peacekeepers who are on the ground and facing that threat directly, and we continue to work with all of the neighbors and others in the international community on options for limiting the control of al-Shabab, pushing them back and supporting the transitional government as it seeks to assert greater authority.

The president is unveiling, for the first time ever, a U.S.

national development strategy, and it is a core pillar of our larger national security strategy, which recognizes that poverty and underdevelopment in various parts of the world pose a threat to peace and security, can fuel conflict and that we have a strategic, as well as a moral and economic interest, in helping poor countries develop.
One of the hallmarks of this strategy is to promote broad-based economic growth, growth that is sustainable, and it benefits the populations of the states concerned.

We recognize that for assistance and support in various forms, whether it's aid, trade, investment, to be effective, it needs optimally to occur in an environment that's conducive, that means where their governance is responsible, where the leadership of the country in question is actually taking steps to facilitate and support development.
And so there will be a greater degree of selectivity.
We're going to seek in the first instance to partner with countries that are pursuing policies that are conducive to development.
